Problem:
class TemperatureControlSystem { double currentTemp; boolean heatOn; void updateTemperature(double externalTemp) { if (externalTemp < 0) { heatOn = true; } else if (externalTemp > 100) { heatOn = false; } if (heatOn) { currentTemp += 5; } else { currentTemp -= 3; } } }",

If the system is modified to increase the temperature addition from 5 to 10 when heatOn is true, will the rate of temperature increase be higher when the external temperature drops below 0?
Explanation: By intervening and modifying the heat application to increase the temperature by 10 instead of 5 when heatOn is true, you directly enhance the effect of the cause (external temperature dropping below 0 causes heatOn to become true). Thus, the rate at which the current temperature increases will be higher.

causal_map: externalTemp < 0 → heatOn = true; heatOn → currentTemp += 5; heatOn = false → currentTemp -= 3; heatOn → temperature addition = 10

Do not provide any final answer to the question. Output strictly in JSON format: {"causal_relation": "<concise natural-language causal description>"}.
causal_map_integration: When externalTemp < 0, heatOn becomes true, which leads to currentTemp increasing by 10 when heatOn is true, resulting in a higher rate of temperature increase compared to the original 5.
